# Estimation: confidence intervals for means {.section-title background-color="#c5b4e3"}

## Using these tools for inference

#### Example: Want to know how much UW students study on average

::: {style="position: absolute; top: 150px; right: 100px; font-size: 3em"}
[$\bar{X}$]{style="color:#1b8883"} ---INFERENCE--> [$\mu_x$]{style="color:#a68100"}
:::

::: {data-id="box2" style="background: #2ad2c9; border: 4px solid #1b8883; border-radius: 15px; width: 550px; padding: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: absolute; bottom: 175px; left: -50px; font-size: 1.25em"}
**Sample statistic**: The characteristic of the sample that we actually observe (i.e. the mean study time of a SAMPLE of UW students)
:::

::: {data-id="box2" style="background: #2ad2c9; border: 4px solid #1b8883; border-radius: 15px; width: 550px; padding: 5px 5px 0px 5px; position: absolute; bottom: 50px; left: -50px;"}
*For example*: draw a random sample of 100 students and observe $\bar{X} = 14.5$
:::

::: {data-id="box4" style="background: #ffc700; border: 4px solid #a68100; border-radius: 15px; width: 550px; padding: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: absolute; bottom: 175px; right: -50px; font-size: 1.25em"}
**Population parameter**: The characteristic of the population that we are interested in knowing (i.e. the mean study time of all UW students)
:::

::: {data-id="box4" style="background: #ffc700; border: 4px solid #a68100; border-radius: 15px; width: 550px; padding: 5px 5px 0px 5px; position: absolute; bottom: 50px; right: -50px;"}
[**Our goal**]{.underline}: Estimate the unknown population parameter $\mu_x = ?$
:::

## Sampling distribution

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="60%"}

<br>
<br>

::: {.fragment style="font-size: 1.75em"}
> [**Sampling Distribution**]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br> A *theoretical* [probability distribution]{.underline} of [all possible sample values]{.underline} for the statistic in which we are interested.
:::
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}

<br> 

::: {.fragment style="font-size: 1.25em"}

### Key tool for inferential statistics

<br>

Allows us to think about how our one single sample result relates to all possible sample results and, by extension, the population we are interested in drawing inferences about.
:::
:::

::::

## Three types of distributions 

![](images/three_dists.png){fig-align="center"}

## Implication of central limit theorem

* [**Central limit theorem**]{.underline} tells us that if the size of our random sample is large enough, we can assume that the sampling distribution of all such possible samples is:
    * Normally distributed
    * Mean: $\mu_\bar{X}$ $= \mu_X$ 
    * Standard Error = [$\sigma_\bar{X}$]{style="color: #a68100"} $= \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}$

::: {data-id="box5" style="background: #ffc700; border: 4px solid #a68100; border-radius: 15px; width: 400px; padding: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: absolute; bottom: 125px; left: -50px; text-align: center; font-size: 1.25em"}
[Standard error]{style="color:#e93cac"}:<br>
The the standard deviation<br>in the sampling distribution<br>
(in this case, of all<br>possible sample means)
:::

::: {style="position: absolute; bottom: -50px; right: -50px;"}

## Confidence intervals

<br>

#### The **BIG IDEA**:

::: incremental
* The sampling distribution and CLT tells us how close to the population mean ($\mu$) the sample mean ($\bar{X}$) is likely to be
* We can use this knowledge to figure out how close the true population mean ($\mu$) is likely to be to the one sample mean ($\bar{X}$)that we observe
* Build a confidence interval around our sample statistic (mean) to define the range in which we think the population parameter can be found...
    * [... and quantify how likely it is that we are right]{style="color:#e93cac"}
:::

---

### [Step 1: Decide on a confidence level and corresponding z-score]{style="font-size: 0.85em"}

::: incremental
* Confidence level (C) refers to the level of confidence that you will have in your inference
    * Example: For a 95% confidence interval, you will be able to say that you are 95% confident that the true population mean falls within the interval
    * More accurately, the probability that the confidence interval contains the actual population parameter
        * 95% of all possible samples of a given size from this population will result in an interval that captures the unknown parameter.
* Most common: [90%]{style="color: #754cbc;"}, [95%]{style="color: #a68100;"}, and [99%]{style="color: #1b8883;"}
:::

---

* Confidence level (C) refers to the level of confidence that you will have in your inference
    * Example: For a 95% confidence interval, you will be able to say that you are 95% confident that the true population mean falls within the interval
    * More accurately, the probability that the confidence interval contains the actual population parameter
        * 95% of all possible samples of a given size from this population will result in an interval that captures the unknown parameter.
* Most common: [90%]{style="color: #754cbc;"}, [95%]{style="color: #a68100;"}, and [99%]{style="color: #1b8883;"}

### [Step 2: Calculate the standard error]{style="font-size: 0.85em"}

* Standard error = standard deviation of the sampling distribution
* Central Limit Theorem tells us: 

::: {style="font-size: 1.5em"}
$$
\sigma_{\bar{X}} = \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}
$$
:::

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
[Example]{.underline style="background: #aadb1e"}: Say you know that your sample of 100 people comes from a population with a standard deviation of 8.0
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #6e8e13"}
$$
\sigma_{\bar{X}} = \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} = \frac{8.0}{\sqrt{100}} = 0.8
$$
:::

[Step 2: Calculate the standard error]{style="color: #bab0ab"}
<br><br>
Step 3: Calculate the margin of error
<br><br>
[Step 4: Calculate the confidence interval]{style="color: #bab0ab"}
<br><br>
[Step 5: Interpret the results]{style="color: #bab0ab"}
:::

---

### [Step 3: Calculate the margin of error]{style="font-size: 0.85em"}

Margin of error = how far out on each side of the sample mean we need to go to define our confidence interval

::: {style="font-size: 1.5em"}
$$
\text{margin of error} = z(\sigma_{\bar{X}}) = z(\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}})
$$
:::

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
Margin of error for our [example]{.underline style="background: #aadb1e"}:
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #6e8e13"}
$$
z(\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}) = (1.96)(0.8)= 1.57
$$
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 style="background: #aadb1e; border: 4px solid #6e8e13; border-radius: 15px; width: 300px; padding: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: absolute; bottom: 50px; right: -75px; text-align: center"}
[Interpretation]{.underline}:<br>Need to go out 1.57 hours on each side of the sample mean to be 95% confident that we have captured the true population mean.
:::


## Calculating confidence intervals

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.25em"}
[Step 1: Decide on a confidence level and corresponding z-score]{style="color: #bab0ab"}
<br><br>
[Step 2: Calculate the standard error]{style="color: #bab0ab"}
<br><br>
[Step 3: Calculate the margin of error]{style="color: #bab0ab"}
<br><br>
Step 4: Calculate the confidence interval
<br><br>
[Step 5: Interpret the results]{style="color: #bab0ab"}
::: 

---

### [Step 4: Calculate the confidence interval]{style="font-size: 0.85em"}

* Add and then subtract the margin of error from the sample mean to get the upper and lower bounds of your confidence interval

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1 data-id="box2" style="background: #2ad2c9; border: 4px solid #1b8883; border-radius: 15px; width: 500px; padding: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: absolute; top: 175px; left: 285px; font-size: 1.25em; text-align: center"}
[Confidence interval]{.underline}:<br>
$\text{sample statistic} \pm \text{margin of error}$
:::

<br>
<br>
<br>
<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
[Example]{.underline style="background: #aadb1e"}:
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #6e8e13"}
$$
14.5 + 1.57 = 16.07
$$

$$
14.5 - 1.57 = 12.93
$$
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 data-id="box2" style="color: #1b8883; border: 4px solid #1b8883; border-radius: 15px; width: 500px; padding: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: absolute; bottom: 0px; right: 25px; font-size: 1.25em; text-align: center"}
$95\%$ confidence interval:<br>
$12.93$ to $16.07$ hours
:::

* A complete interpretation of a confidence interval has three components

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}

We are [**$95\%$ confident**]{style="color: #e93cac"} that the true average number of hours studied for the [**population**]{style="color: #e93cac"} of UW students is between [**$12.93$ to $16.07$**]{style="color: #e93cac"} hours
:::

## [Factors affecting precision (width) of the confidence interval]{style="font-size: 0.75em"}

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
* Which confidence interval would you prefer?

    <br>
    [OR]{.center}
    * Average study time of UW students is between **14.25 and 14.75 hours**

All else being equal, the second one is preferable because it is more [**precise**]{style="color: white"}
<br>
**(narrower, with smaller margin of error)**

$$
\text{margin of error} = z(\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}})
$$
:::

::: fragment
* [Confidence level]{.underline}
    * Trade-off: higher confidence = lower precision (higher margin of error)
:::

::: {.fragment style="border: 3px solid black; border-radius: 15px; width: 1000px; padding: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: static;"}
|   | 50%  | 60%  | 70%  | 80%  | 90%  | 95%  | 96%  | 98%  | 99%  | 99.5%  | 99.9%  |

: Z-scores come from Standard Normal Table {tbl-colwidths="[8.333]"}
::: 


::: fragment
* [Sample size]{.underline}
    * Larger sample = smaller standard error = greater precision (lower margin of error)
:::

::: fragment
* [Level of variation in the population]{.underline}
    * More variation in population = more variation in possible sample results = larger standard error = bigger margin of error
:::

# Estimation: confidence intervals for proportions {.section-title background-color="#c5b4e3"}

## [Estimating Population Proportions (or percentages)]{style="font-size: 0.85em"}

::: fragment
#### Goal:

* Use the sample proportion ($\widehat{p}$) to construct a confidence interval in which we believe the true population proportion ($P$)^[Sometimes $\pi$] is located
:::

::: fragment
Example:

* Want to know the proportion of UW students who are employed during the school year
* Population proportion, $P$, is not observable
* Use sample information to estimate $P$
    * $n = 200$
    * Sample proportion, $\hat{p} = 0.42$

:::

## Confidence intervals

::: {style="font-size:2em"}
$$
\widehat{p}
$$
:::

::: {data-id="box2" style="border: 3px solid #e93cac; border-radius:5px; position: absolute; top: 145px; left: 85px; width: 400px; height: 0px; font-size: 0.75em; text-align: center"}

:::

:::

Create our 95% confidence interval by going 1.96 standard errors on each side of the sample proportion
:::

::: {data-id="box5" style="background: #c5b4e3; border: 4px solid #754cbc; border-radius: 15px; padding: 10px 10px 10px 10px; position: absolute; top: 425px; left: 225px"}
Building a [*margin of error*]{style="color:#e93cac"} around our sample mean
:::

::: {data-id="box2" style="background: #2ad2c9; border: 4px solid #1b8883; border-radius: 15px; width: 500px; padding: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: absolute; bottom: 25px; left: 285px; font-size: 1.25em; text-align: center"}
[Confidence interval]{.underline}:<br>
$\text{sample statistic} \pm \text{margin of error}$
:::

## Calculating confidence intervals

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.25em"}
Step 1: Decide on a confidence level and corresponding z-score
<br><br>
Step 2: Calculate the standard error
<br><br>
Step 3: Calculate the margin of error
<br><br>
Step 4: Calculate the confidence interval
<br><br>
Step 5: Interpret the results
:::

---

### [Step 1: Decide on a confidence level and corresponding z-score]{style="font-size: 0.85em"}

::: incremental
* Confidence level (C) refers to the level of confidence that you will have in your inference
    * Example: For a 95% confidence interval, you will be able to say that you are 95% confident that the true population mean falls within the interval
    * More accurately, the probability that the confidence interval contains the actual population parameter
        * 95% of all possible samples of a given size from this population will result in an interval that captures the unknown parameter.
* Most common: [90%]{style="color: #754cbc;"}, [95%]{style="color: #a68100;"}, and [99%]{style="color: #1b8883;"}
:::

---

### [Step 1: Decide on a confidence level and corresponding z-score]{style="font-size: 0.85em"}

* Confidence level (C) refers to the level of confidence that you will have in your inference
    * Example: For a 95% confidence interval, you will be able to say that you are 95% confident that the true population mean falls within the interval
    * More accurately, the probability that the confidence interval contains the actual population parameter
        * 95% of all possible samples of a given size from this population will result in an interval that captures the unknown parameter.
* Most common: [90%]{style="color: #754cbc;"}, [95%]{style="color: #a68100;"}, and [99%]{style="color: #1b8883;"}

|   | 50%  | 60%  | 70%  | 80%  | 90%  | 95%  | 96%  | 98%  | 99%  | 99.5%  | 99.9%  |
|:----:|:----:|:----:|:----:|:----:|:----:|:----:|:----:|:----:|:----:|:----:|:----:|
| **Z\*** | 0.674  | 0.841 | 1.036 | 1.282 | [1.645]{style="background: #c5b4e3;"} | [1.960]{style="background: #ffc700;"} | 2.054 | 2.326 | [2.576]{style="background: #2ad2c9;"} | 2.807 | 3.291 |

: Z-scores come from Standard Normal Table {tbl-colwidths="[8.333]"}

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1 data-id="box4" style="background: #ffc700; border: 4px solid #a68100; border-radius: 15px; width: 750px; padding: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: absolute; bottom: 50px; left: 150px; text-align: center"}
To create a $95\%$ confidence interval, go out $1.96$ standard errors on each side of the sample mean
:::

---

### [Step 2: Calculate the standard error]{style="font-size: 0.85em"}

* Standard error = standard deviation of the sampling distribution
* Central Limit Theorem tells us: 

::: {style="font-size: 1.5em"}
$$
\sigma_{\widehat{p}} = \sqrt{\frac{\widehat{p}(1-\widehat{p})}{n}}
$$
:::

::: {style="border: 3px solid black; border-radius: 15px; width: 350px; margin: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: absolute; top: 200px; right: -50px; text-align: center"}
where $\widehat{p}$ = sample proportion <br> $n$ = sample size
:::

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
[Example]{.underline style="background: #aadb1e"}: With sample size of 200 and sample proportion of 0.42
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #6e8e13"}
$$
\sigma_{\widehat{p}} = \sqrt{\frac{\widehat{p}(1-\widehat{p})}{n}} = \sqrt{\frac{0.42(1-0.42)}{200}} = 0.035
$$
:::

---

### [Step 3: Calculate the margin of error]{style="font-size: 0.85em"}

Margin of error = how far out on each side of the sample mean we need to go to define our confidence interval

::: {style="font-size: 1.5em"}
$$
\text{margin of error} = z(\sigma_{\widehat{p}}) = z(\sqrt{\frac{\widehat{p}(1-\widehat{p})}{n}})
$$
:::

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
Margin of error for our [example]{.underline style="background: #aadb1e"}:
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #6e8e13"}
$$
z(\sqrt{\frac{\widehat{p}(1-\widehat{p})}{n}}) = (1.96)(0.035) = 0.069
$$
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 style="background: #aadb1e; border: 4px solid #6e8e13; border-radius: 15px; width: 250px; padding: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: absolute; bottom: 100px; right: -85px; text-align: center; font-size: 0.75em"}
[Interpretation]{.underline}:<br>Need to go out 0.069 in each direction of the sample proportion to be 95% confident that we have captured the true population proportion.
:::

---

### [Step 4: Calculate the confidence interval]{style="font-size: 0.85em"}

* Add and then subtract the margin of error from the sample mean to get the upper and lower bounds of your confidence interval

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1 data-id="box2" style="background: #2ad2c9; border: 4px solid #1b8883; border-radius: 15px; width: 500px; padding: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: absolute; top: 175px; left: 285px; font-size: 1.25em; text-align: center"}
[Confidence interval]{.underline}:<br>
$\text{sample statistic} \pm \text{margin of error}$
:::

<br>
<br>
<br>
<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
[Example]{.underline style="background: #aadb1e"}:
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #6e8e13"}
$$
0.42 + 0.069 = 0.489
$$

$$
0.42 - 0.069 = 0.351
$$
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 data-id="box2" style="color: #1b8883; border: 4px solid #1b8883; border-radius: 15px; width: 500px; padding: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: absolute; bottom: 0px; right: 25px; font-size: 1.25em; text-align: center"}
$95\%$ confidence interval:<br>
$0.351$ to $0.489$
:::

---

### [Step 5: Interpret the results]{style="font-size: 0.85em"}

* A complete interpretation of a confidence interval has three components

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
1. Level of [**confidence**]{style="color: #e93cac"} (usually 90%, 95%, 99%)
2. Reference to the [**population parameter**]{style="color: #e93cac"} being estimated
3. The [**interval**]{style="color: #e93cac"} of values (or at least the sample statistic and margin of error)
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
[Example]{.underline style="background: #aadb1e"}:
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 data-id="box2" style="color: #6e8e13; border: 4px solid #6e8e13; border-radius: 15px; width: 400px; padding: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: absolute; bottom: 250px; right: 300px; font-size: 1.25em; text-align: center"}
$95\%$ confidence interval:<br>
$0.351$ to $0.489$
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 data-id="box2" style="border: 4px solid #e93cac; border-radius: 15px; width: 800px; padding: 5px 5px 5px 5px; position: absolute; bottom: 50px; right: 0px; font-size: 1.25em; text-align: center"}
We are [**$95\%$ confident**]{style="color: #e93cac"} that between [**$35.1\%$ and $48.9\%$**]{style="color: #e93cac"} of the [**population of students**]{style="color: #e93cac"} are employed during the school year.
:::
